title: The Story of McDonalds
section: What you should eat at McDonald‚Äôs
text:
What you should eat at McDonald‚Äôs

A Correlation Plot
The correlation plot in provides a visual representation of the relationship between different nutritional components in McDonald‚Äôs food.


The x and y axes represent the nutritional components, and each square in the grid represents the correlation between two components. The color of the squares ranges from red to yellow, with red indicating a strong negative correlation and yellow indicating a strong positive correlation. You can hover over a square to see the exact correlation coefficient. The chart also includes checkboxes for selecting which variables to include in the plot. This interactivity allows you to customize the chart based on your specific interests and needs.
For instance, a strong positive correlation between calories and fat would suggest that foods with higher calorie content tend to also be higher in fat. This information can be useful when deciding what to eat at McDonald‚Äôs, as it allows us to make more informed decisions based on our dietary needs and preferences. For example, if we are trying to limit our intake of saturated fat, we might choose foods that are low in calories, assuming they are negatively correlated. It is also interesting to note that the darkest red on the plot are sugar and salt, which makes a lot of sense considering how most salty food items are normally not sweet, vice versa.

title: The Story of McDonalds
text:
The Big Mac Price


The Big Mac Index, invented by The Economist in 1986, is a lighthearted guide to whether currencies are at their ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù level. It‚Äôs based on the theory of purchasing-power parity (PPP), the notion that in the long run exchange rates should move towards the rate that would equalize the prices of an identical basket of goods and services (in this case, a burger) in any two countries.
In this chart, the first thing we notice would be how during the 2008 Financial Crisis, the Big Mac Prices dropped globally.

title: The Story of McDonalds
section: McDonald‚Äôs All Around the World (As of 2022)
text:
McDonald‚Äôs All Around the World (As of 2022)



McDonald‚Äôs Density Hot Spots
With the ‚ÄòMcDonald‚Äôs Outlets per Million Residents‚Äô toggle activated, a clear trend emerges ‚Äì the density of McDonald‚Äôs locations is notably high in the US, Canada, Europe, and Australia. This concentration indicates a strong presence in these regions relative to their populations. However, the story takes an interesting turn when we examine countries with the least dense McDonald‚Äôs to Population ratio, such as Peru, Egypt, and India.


The Golden Arches and GDP
When toggling on ‚ÄòGDP per Capita‚Äô, you may notice that there is barely any changes in colour, save a few countries like China and some regions in Europe etc. The graph shows that there is a positive correlation between GDP per capita and the number of McDonald‚Äôs outlets in a country. This is consistent with the findings from the first graph, which showed that wealthier countries tend to have more McDonald‚Äôs outlets per million residents.
This correlation can be explained by a number of factors, including:

Wealthier countries tend to have more urbanization and higher levels of disposable income. This creates a larger market for fast food restaurants like McDonald‚Äôs.
Wealthier countries also tend to have more foreign direct investment. McDonald‚Äôs is one of the world‚Äôs largest foreign direct investors, and it has a long history of expanding into new markets.
Some people argue that McDonald‚Äôs is a symbol of Western culture and globalization. Wealthier countries are more likely to be exposed to Western culture and globalization, and this may lead to a greater demand for McDonald‚Äôs restaurants.



Exploring Disparities
The countries with lower McDonald‚Äôs density often share common characteristics. Many are classified as developing nations, where disposable income is limited, and supply chains pose considerable challenges. Additionally, some countries attribute their low McDonald‚Äôs density to political reasons, a small local population, or simply a lack of affinity for American fast-food burgers.


Africa: A Unique Landscape
Zooming in on Africa, a continent seemingly devoid of McDonald‚Äôs presence, we uncover a myriad of factors influencing this phenomenon.







Factors
Implications




Economic Challenges
Africa‚Äôs diverse economic landscape poses challenges like poverty, political instability, and underdeveloped infrastructure. These hurdles can hinder McDonald‚Äôs efforts to establish profitable operations in certain regions.


Cultural Diversity
Africa‚Äôs rich culinary heritage presents a complex challenge. While McDonald‚Äôs adapts menus to local tastes, achieving a balance between global consistency and diverse local preferences becomes intricate in a continent with such culinary variety.


Supply Chain Struggles
McDonald‚Äôs stringent quality standards rely on efficient supply chains. Inadequate infrastructure, including transportation and logistics, in Africa can impede the reliable supply of ingredients, affecting the company‚Äôs quality standards.


Fierce Competition
The fast-food industry in Africa is fiercely competitive, with local and international chains vying for market share. Entering this market demands careful research and an effective competitive strategy.


Regulatory Complexities
Different African countries have varying regulations for foreign businesses. Navigating these diverse regulatory frameworks can be time-consuming and financially burdensome for McDonald‚Äôs.

Attaching package: 'maps'

# Add country code
outlets <- outlets %>%
  mutate(country_code = countrycode(Country, "country.name", "iso3c"),
         outlets_per_mil = `Number of Restaurants per Million Population`,
         num_outlets = `Number of Restaurants`) %>%
  select(-`Number of Restaurants per Million Population`, -`Number of Restaurants`)

# Create a lookup table for latitudes and longitudes

  distinct(country.etc, lat, long) %>%
  rename(Country = country.etc)
world_cities <- world_cities %>%
  mutate(Country = case_when(
    Country == "Bahamas" ~ "The Bahamas",
    Country == "Korea South" ~ "South Korea",
    TRUE ~ Country
  ))

outlets <- left_join(outlets, world_cities, by = "Country")
centroids <- outlets %>%
  group_by(Country) %>%
  summarize(
    centroid_lat = mean(lat, na.rm = TRUE),
    centroid_long = mean(long, na.rm = TRUE)
  )
outlets <- left_join(outlets, centroids, by = "Country") %>% select(-"lat", -"long") %>% distinct()

outlets <- outlets  %>%
    mutate(Country = tolower(Country)) # Ensure country names are in lowercase for matching
world_countries <- ne_countries(scale = "medium", returnclass = "sf")

# Join with your data
outlets <- world_countries %>%
    left_join(outlets, by = c("adm0_a3" = "country_code")) %>% 
    select("name","outlets_per_mil", "num_outlets", "First Opening", "pop_est", "gdp_md_est", "economy", "income_grp", "geometry", "centroid_lat","centroid_long") %>% na.omit()

outlets_wkt <- outlets
outlets_wkt$geometry <- st_as_text(outlets$geometry)


# Write updated dataset
write_csv(outlets_wkt, "outlets.csv")

It‚Äôs based on the theory of purchasing-power parity (PPP), the notion that in the long run exchange rates should move towards the rate that would equalize the prices of an identical basket of goods and services (in this case, a burger) in any two countries.


This interactive chart highlights key moments in history, with notable increases coinciding with McDonald‚Äôs ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Lovin‚Äô It‚Äù campaign in 2003 and a downturn following the release of the ‚ÄúSuper Size Me‚Äù documentary in 2004. The Global Financial Crisis of 2007-2009 also significantly impacted the Big Mac Index. Surprisingly, the COVID-19 lockdowns in 2020 had a relatively modest effect, possibly due to widespread delivery options and the relative affordability of McDonald‚Äôs compared to other food choices.
